    >           Course Detail                                        First-Year Writing Seminar: Contemplation and Culture                                Semester and Year        FA 2012                    Course Number        FIRST-UG385                    Section        001                    Instructor        Jean Gallagher                    Days                            Tue,Thu                                 Time                            11:00 AM -       12:15 PM                                Units        4.0                    Level        U                    Foundation Requirement                                         Notes/Restrictions       Open to Gallatin first-year students only.                    Description       There is a significant body of cultural work that seeks to describe the experience or results of contemplation or meditation, offer instruction in its various methods, or to induce or encourage a contemplative state. This course will examine texts and images from a number of fields (including spiritual autobiography, sermons, psychological studies, philosophical writing, painting, and poetry) and from a range of religious and philosophical traditions (Christian mysticism, Daoism, Buddhism, Sufism), which represent some aspect of contemplative experience. Readings may include works by James Austin, Karen Armstrong, Meister Eckhart, Teresa of Avila, Simone Weil, William James, Rainer Maria Rilke, William Blake, Eihei Dogen, Lao-tzu, Walt Whitman, Gerard Manley Hopkins, Gary Snyder, Dante Alighieri, Jelaluddin Rumi, and Basho; visual art may include work by Duccio, Mark Rothko, Barnett Newman, Wassily Kandinsky, and Bill Viola. Writing in the course will include a daily journal (which will include observations of assigned readings or images), four shorter essays (4-5 pages), and a longer critical essay (6-8 pages).        Writing          >           Writing Courses                            Writing Courses         With more than 30 writing courses each semester, Gallatin students have the opportunity to engage in diverse genres and writing practices.   First-Year Writing and Research Seminars use writing to explore a particular theme while helping students to develop their critical writing skills. Recent examples include “ Aesthetics on Trial ,” “ Contemplation and Culture ,” and “ Science Fiction: Frankenstein and Revisions .”   After taking the foundation courses, Gallatin students may choose from a rich variety of Advanced Writing Courses including fiction, poetry, creative nonfiction, comedy-writing, and documentary-writing, as well inter-genre, theme-based writing courses. B.A. English, Queens College, CUNY, 1985 Ph.D. English, CUNY Graduate Center, 1994           Jean Gallagher is a Professor of English at Polytechnic Institute of NYU. She is the author of three collections of poetry (  This Minute  , which received the Poets Out Loud Prize from Fordham University Press),  Stubborn  (winner of the FIELD Prize from Oberlin College Press), and  Start  , just out from Oberlin College Press. She also is the author of  The World Wars through the Female Gaze  (Southern Illinois UP), and has published critical essays on gender, modernist literature, and visual culture.                                     top of page                                     Contact Information     Jean Gallagher             Professor of English, NYU Poly              jgallagh@poly.edu             See Profes, Room Email                           Office Hours         Monday Leave             Tuesday Leave             Wednesday Leave             Thursday Leave               Friday Leave                                                Courses                                                   2014             Fall                            Transfer Student Research Seminar: Buddhism and Culture in the U.S.                  Mon,Wed      9:30 AM -      10:45 AM                                                   2013             Spring                            First-Year Research Seminar: Buddha Studio: The Art of Practice and the Practice of Art                  Tue,Thu      9:30 AM -      10:45 AM                                                   2013             Fall                            First-Year Writing Seminar: Contemplation and Culture                  Mon,Wed      12:30 PM -      1:45 PM                                                   2012             Fall                            First-Year Writing Seminar: Contemplation and Culture                  Tue,Thu      11:00 AM -      12:15 PM                                       Research and Teaching Interests       poetry and poetics;
